summary: This document is an email from whistleblower Christopher J Dilorio to an SEC official named Janey, appealing the preliminary denial of his award application. It contains allegations of a vast conspiracy involving Knight Capital/KCG/VIRT (NITE), the SEC, FINRA, and others, accusing them of facilitating market manipulation, naked short selling, and money laundering through shell companies. It references specific individuals and entities involved in these alleged schemes. This document is a lengthy whistleblower email from Christopher J. Dilorio to the SEC, detailing allegations of a massive, ongoing securities fraud and money laundering scheme involving penny stock shells, broker-dealers like Knight/NITE/Virtu, and entities such as UBS, Hanover/Magna, and JMJ Financial. Dilorio accuses the SEC of criminal obstruction, using his whistleblower information to both bring and obstruct complaints while denying him compensation. The email references multiple prior TCRs (Tips, Complaints, and Referrals) and connects the fraud to figures like Michael Milken, Josh Sason, and various political and financial networks.

persons.name: Christopher J Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the email, appealing the SEC's preliminary denial of his award application and alleging a vast conspiracy involving market manipulation and money laundering.

persons.name: Janey
persons.context: Recipient of the email, the SEC official who issued the preliminary denial of Dilorio's award application.

persons.name: Hoecker
persons.context: Mentioned as a colleague of Janey and part of the SEC apparatus allegedly involved in obstructing or facilitating the criminal enterprise.

persons.name: Clayton
persons.context: Referred to as the SEC Chairman who allegedly failed to disclose conflicts of interest related to Sullivan & Cromwell, Fishman, and NITE, and is called to step down.

persons.name: Joshie Sason
persons.context: Allegedly involved with Hanover/Magna and various shell companies (CGFIA, IMDS, NewLead, FreeSeas, PRTH) in money laundering schemes, as detailed in Dilorio's TCR and an SEC complaint.

persons.name: Justin Keener
persons.context: Allegedly involved with JMJ in illegal activity and money laundering through shells like Blink Charging (fka New Image Concepts). Barred by FINRA as a 'Bad Actor' in 2013.

persons.name: McKessy
persons.context: Mentioned as being in possession of Dilorio's 2013 TCR filed with Berger for several years.

persons.name: Berger
persons.context: The official with whom Dilorio filed his 2013 TCR.

persons.name: Jaclin
persons.context: Named in a 2016 SEC 'Shell factory' complaint related to New Image Concepts, prior to Keener's involvement.

persons.name: Fishman
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of Clayton's undisclosed conflicts of interest.

persons.name: Christopher J. Dilorio
persons.context: Author of the email and primary whistleblower alleging massive securities fraud, money laundering, and SEC obstruction. He details his extensive TCR submissions and correspondence with regulators.

persons.name: Justin W. Keener
persons.context: Operated JMJ Financial; charged by SEC in 2020 for unregistered penny stock dealing; alleged to be involved in money laundering shells like IMDS and CGFIA.

persons.name: Joshua Sason
persons.context: Charged by SEC in 2019 for microcap frauds and unlawful offerings; linked to Hanover/Magna and money laundering shells like NewLead and FreeSeas.

persons.name: Michael Farkas
persons.context: CEO of Blink; previously involved with Skyway Communications, whose registration was revoked by SEC in 2007.

persons.name: Jonathan New
persons.context: CFO of Blink; formerly CFO of AQR/Crede, linked to Milken money laundering.

persons.name: Donald Engel
persons.context: Director of Blink; worked at Drexel with Michael Milken.

persons.name: Gregg Jaclin
persons.context: Attorney linked to Honig's shell factory; barred as an SEC lawyer.

persons.name: Brian Colleran
persons.context: Linked to Trump Cleveland fundraiser and healthcare fraud; associated with Millennium Bio/Inergetics shell.

persons.name: Jane Norberg
persons.context: Chief of the SEC Office of the Whistleblower; recipient of Dilorio's appeal and correspondence.

persons.name: Sean McKessy
persons.context: Former chief of the SEC OWB; solicited more information from Dilorio after his TCR submission.

persons.name: Robin Traxler
persons.context: FINRA official with whom Dilorio had extensive correspondence in 2012 regarding penny stock shells CGFIA and AppTech.

persons.name: Dan Coleman
persons.context: CEO of KCG after merger; previously ran Equities at UBS during Reg SHO violations.

persons.name: Oleg Firer
persons.context: CEO of Net Element (NETE), a suspected money laundering shell; former head of Acies.

persons.name: Terren Peizer
persons.context: Linked to Milken/Drexel and obstruction of justice; involved with Crede and Net Element.

persons.name: Michael Wachs
persons.context: Felon partner of Terren Peizer; linked to Crede and Net Element offerings.

persons.name: Martin Schlaff
persons.context: Austria/Israel-based controller of Alpha Capital Anstalt, linked to money laundering shells.

persons.name: Jay Clayton
persons.context: SEC Chair linked to criminal obstruction; his firm Sullivan Cromwell advised Knight/KCG/Virtu.

persons.name: Jared Fishman
persons.context: Attorney at Sullivan Cromwell who advised Knight/KCG/Virtu transactions, allegedly facilitating fraud.

persons.name: Carl Hoecker
persons.context: SEC IG accused by Dilorio of criminal obstruction for not interviewing him or informing Congress of serious allegations.

persons.name: David Urban
persons.context: Trump PA Campaign Manager who sits on the NITE Board of Directors and is involved with money laundering shell FSD Parma.

persons.name: Michael Milken
persons.context: Central figure linked to numerous entities and individuals in the alleged fraud network, including Drexel, junk bonds, and money laundering shells.

persons.name: Rich Handler
persons.context: Milken/Drexel protégé; involved in repeated bailouts of NITE.

persons.name: Leon Black
persons.context: Linked to Milken, Epstein, and money laundering shell ESWW.

persons.name: Steven Mnuchin
persons.context: Linked to Milken, Black, Epstein, and junk bonds/S&L bailouts.

persons.name: Cromwell Coulson
persons.context: Chaired FINRA Market Regulation Committee; linked to the existence of OTCM for abusive naked shorting.

persons.name: Andrew Wimpfheimer
persons.context: Former NITE trader and founding OTC Markets Board member.

persons.name: Vikas Arora
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who met with Dilorio in Denver in 2016 regarding his TCR.

persons.name: Nathan Sarnacki
persons.context: IRS Criminal Investigation agent who met with Dilorio in Denver in 2016.

persons.name: John McCarthy
persons.context: Former SEC NY official who ended up as Knight/KCG Chief Counsel; linked to Madoff investigation failures.

events.title: Dilorio files TCR with SEC
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed a TCR (Tip, Complaint or Referral) with SEC official Berger, detailing allegations against various entities and individuals.

events.title: FINRA bars Justin Keener
events.description: FINRA barred Justin Keener/JMJ as a 'Bad Actor' related to inadequate anti-money laundering programs and other violations.

events.title: SEC files 'Shell factory' complaint
events.description: The SEC filed a complaint (Jaclin et al) against a 'shell factory' operation, which included New Image Concepts.

events.title: Dilorio's appeal email
events.description: Christopher Dilorio sends a formal appeal email to SEC official Janey, alleging ongoing criminal activity and SEC obstruction.

events.title: Dilorio's First Whistleblower Complaint
events.description: Christopher Dilorio filed his first whistleblower complaint with the SEC, detailing massive fraud implicating Knight/NITE and UBS.

events.title: Knight Capital Trading 'Glitch'
events.description: Knight Capital experienced a massive trading loss due to a software glitch, leading to an emergency bailout. Dilorio alleges this proved Knight was insolvent and revealed accounting fraud.

events.title: Dilorio's Amended TCR with Berger Montague
events.description: Dilorio submitted an amended TCR with law firm Berger Montague to the SEC, detailing illegal activity at Knight/NITE and UBS.

events.title: SEC Oppenheimer AML Action
events.description: SEC brought administrative proceeding against Oppenheimer & Co. for anti-money laundering failures, which Dilorio claims was based on his information.

events.title: SEC Charges Against Joshua Sason et al.
events.description: SEC charged Joshua Sason and others for roles in microcap frauds and unlawful offerings, which Dilorio claims was based on his TCRs.

events.title: SEC Charges Justin Keener/JMJ Financial
events.description: SEC charged Justin W. Keener d/b/a JMJ Financial as an unregistered penny stock dealer, which Dilorio claims was based on his information.

events.title: Virtu Acquisition of KCG
events.description: Virtu Financial acquired KCG Holdings. Dilorio alleges the transaction was fraudulent, with overpayment for an insolvent entity and omission of key financials.

locations: Santa Monica, California (HQ of New Concepts)
Miami Beach, Florida (residence of Justin Keener)
Fort Lauderdale, Florida (residence of David Della Sciucca Jr.)
Jersey City, New Jersey (location of NITE/Virtu)
Denver, Colorado (location of CGFIA 'world HQ' and meeting with IRS CI)
Neuchatel, Switzerland (location linked to Guyer and Antelope Technologies)
Highlands Ranch, Colorado (office of Antelope Technologies)
Frisco, Texas (base of Strata Coal Company)
keyFacts: The whistleblower, Christopher J Dilorio, alleges a vast, ongoing conspiracy involving Knight Capital/KCG/VIRT (NITE), the SEC, and FINRA to facilitate market manipulation, naked short selling, and money laundering.

Dilorio claims the SEC's Obligation Warehouse (OW) is an illegal mechanism created to help NITE circumvent Rule 204 of Reg SHO and continue criminal activity, posing a risk to the public as of June 2020.

Specific individuals like 'Bag Men' Joshie Sason (Hanover/Magna) and Justin Keener (JMJ) are accused of running money laundering operations through numerous shell companies (e.g., CGFIA, IMDS, NewLead, FreeSeas, PRTH, Blink Charging).
SEC Chairman Clayton is accused of failing to disclose conflicts of interest related to Sullivan & Cromwell, Fishman, and NITE, and is called to step down immediately.

The document references specific regulatory actions, including a 2013 FINRA fine against three firms for inadequate AML programs and the 2016 SEC 'Shell factory' complaint, as evidence supporting Dilorio's allegations.

The whistleblower, Christopher Dilorio, alleges the SEC has engaged in criminal obstruction by using his whistleblower information to both bring and obstruct complaints while denying him compensation.

Dilorio claims Knight Capital (NITE) was insolvent as early as 2011 and that its core business is abusive naked shorting of OTCM shells to facilitate money laundering, a scheme allegedly known and facilitated by the SEC and FINRA.
Key entities implicated include Knight/NITE/Virtu, UBS, Hanover/Magna, JMJ Financial, and a network of 'shell factories' linked to figures like Michael Milken, Joshua Sason, and Justin Keener.

The document references the 2012 Knight trading 'glitch' as a bailout of a 'known criminal enterprise' and alleges the subsequent Virtu acquisition of KCG involved fraudulent overpayment and omission of financials.

Dilorio provides specific evidence, including a CGFIA 10-Q filing referencing a DTCC 'Global Lock' due to actions by a third-party broker-dealer, which he cites as incontrovertible proof of naked shorting.
